list.title: Question 114
list.content: The table shows the number of chromosomes found in the gametes of various species.SpeciesHaploid chromosome number (n)Parascaris equorum(horse threadworm)2Vicia faba(field bean)6Oryza sativa(rice)12Homo sapiens(human)23Pan troglodytes(chimpanzee)24Canis familiaris(dog)39What can be concluded from the data in the table?I.Diploid cells usually have an even number of chromosomes.II.Species with more chromosomes have a larger genome size.III.Humans are most closely related toPan troglodytes.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because diploid cells have an even number of chromosomes (Statement I) unless affected by errors such as non-disjunction. This can be obtained by doubling the haploid number in the table and recognising that an odd number of diploid chromosomes cannot be evenly distributed to form gametes.Statement IIis false because the number of chromosomes an organism has is not an accurate reflection of its genome size.Oryza sativa, for example, has a much larger genome than any of the other species in the table despite having fewer chromosomes.Statement IIIis false because although humans are closely related to chimpanzees, this cannot be concluded from the data in the table alone.Stipa spartea(porcupine grass), for example, has the same number of chromosomes as humans but is not closely related.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect because they contain one or more false statements.

list.title: Question 115
list.content:
The diagram below shows a water column inside a xylem vessel:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f1b2aab-acf0-4771-9f33-131080adcc07/images/50f324b6-f19a-4ec4-ad52-e24066bb9bc2/BI2865%20A1.1%20core%20MCQ.jpeg.JPEG)

[Sources: Adapted from Chan, T (26 May 2025),File: Capillary Action in Plants [image]. Retrieved 5 June 2025 from https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9c/Capillary_Action_in_Plants.jpg. CC BY-SA 4.0]Which of the following best explains how the property illustrated contributes to plant survival?I.Cohesion between molecules allows tension to be transmitted up the xylem.II.Cohesion enables    water to evaporate more easily.III.Adhesion prevents the water column from breaking.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because cohesion refers to the attraction between water molecules due to hydrogen bonding. This cohesive property allows the water column to behave as a continuous stream, enabling tension created by transpiration at the leaves to be transmitted all the way down the xylem. This is central to the cohesion-tension theory of water transport.Statement IIis false because cohesion actually resists evaporation. The hydrogen bonds between water molecules make it harder for individual molecules to escape into the air. Evaporation is more closely influenced by temperature and humidity, not directly by cohesion.Statement IIIis true because adhesion is the attraction between water molecules and the walls of the xylem vessel. This helps to counteract gravity and supports the column, reducing the chance of it breaking, especially under tension during transpiration. So this contributes to the integrity of the water column.Choice Cis therefore the correct answer because it only includes the two trueStatements IandIII.Choice Ais incorrect as it is missing the trueStatement III.Choices BandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement II.

list.title: Question 116
list.content: Which approach, carried out by conservationists in zoos and botanical gardens, defines the transition betweenex-situconservation andin-situconservation?A.\hspace{1em}Building more capacity in zoos and botanical gardens.B.\hspace{1em}Carrying out artificial selection within zoos and botanical gardens.C.\hspace{1em}Building the population of captive-bred species across zoos and botanical gardens in many countries.D.\hspace{1em}Release of captive-bred species from zoos and botanical gardens into nature reserves.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the transfer of ex-situ to in-situ means the return of species from captivity to areas that could become their natural habitats again. Nature reserves increase the chances of successful re-introduction, although many other measures would have to be taken to ensure success.Choice Ais incorrect because building more captive breeding areas will not increase the chances of being able to reintroduce species back into the wild.Choice Bis incorrect because, whilst artificial selection would allow desirable traits to be selected for in captivity, this would not necessarily guarantee that species would thrive or even survive in a wild habitat again. Artificial selection would also take a long time (measured in years and decades for some species in particular), as successive generations are bred.Choice Cis incorrect because having more animals in captivity and plants in botanical gardens would do little to increase the chances of those species being successfully reintroduced to the wild. A large captive population serves no natural purpose to conservation unless a species is released into the wild at some stage. Keeping species in captive breeding might be called ‘preservation’, but it is not ‘conservation’ in its truest sense.

list.title: Question 117
list.content: Outline why scientists must have several approaches to conserve biodiversity.[3]There are approximately 80 Javan Rhinoceros (Rhinoceros sondaicus) in the world. Discuss the environmental and economic implications the Indonesian government must consider before volunteering the Javan Rhinoceros to the EDGE programme.[5]Explain why rapid human population growth is linked to the current biodiversity crisis.[7]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​no single approach is sufficientORestablishing conservation areas is often effective, but without reintroduction of lost species it will have limited successORother suitable example showing that when one approach is used, another is required for effective conservation[1]→\ce{ -> }​different speciesORecosystems require different measures[1]→\ce{ -> }​not all methods are affordable for different countriesORorganisations,ORgovernments[1]→\ce{ -> }​biodiversity encompasses a vast range of organisms, habitats, and ecosystems with different interdependencies[1]→\ce{ -> }​socio-economic factors need to be considered to ensure that conservation efforts take into account local communities' needs and interests[1]→\ce{ -> }​ongoing changes in biodiversity may mean that strategies need to be adapted accordingly[1]→\ce{ -> }​multiple approaches can create a more resilient and effective conservation strategy[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Scientists must have multiple approaches to conserve biodiversity asno single approachis sufficient (✓\checkmark✓), different species requiredifferent methods(✓\checkmark✓) and not all methods areaffordable for different governments(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfiveof the following (implications must be stated):Environmental negative considerations→\ce{ -> }​disruption of current food chainsORwebs[1]Environmental positive considerations→\ce{ -> }​restoration of food websORchains[1]→\ce{ -> }​habitatsORforests will have to be restored[1]→\ce{ -> }​the Javan Rhinoceros is a keystone species, so conserving this species would indirectly protect the ecosystem[1]Economic negative considerations→\ce{ -> }​can be expensive to put rhinos in breeding programmesORzoos,OREDGE program would require financial investments in researchORmonitoring,ORconservation initiatives[1]→\ce{ -> }​land that has been used for urbanisationORbusinessesORagriculture  will have to be reforested[1]→\ce{ -> }​local communities might rely on the same resources as the rhinoceros,ORlocal communities' livelihoods might be impacted by conservation measures[1]Economic positive considerations→\ce{ -> }​increase tourism in the area[1]→\ce{ -> }​may improve international cooperationORtrade agreements,ORforeign investments[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Before volunteering the Javan rhinoceros to the EDGE programme, economic considerations must be taken into account.  For example, protecting the Javan rhinoceros would likelyincrease tourismin the area (✓\checkmark✓) as people will travel to the country to see the rhinos. However, it can beexpensiveto put rhinos intobreeding programmes(✓\checkmark✓) orreforestland that has beenurbanised(✓\checkmark✓), and this may beunaffordablefor the Indonesian government. A positive environmental consideration is thatreforestation will increase biodiversity(✓\checkmark✓) in the area. However, it may also result indisruption of current, stable food chains(✓\checkmark✓)in the area.Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​more huntingORpoachingORfor foodORresources, which endangers animals[1]→\ce{ -> }​loss of habitats due to urbanisationORagriculture[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased agriculture can lead to a monocultureORa loss in diversity[1]→\ce{ -> }​deforestation for building infrastructureORresources such as paperORagriculture[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased pollution due to increased vehiclesORglobal transportORindustryORfactories can cause damage to organismsORcontribute to global warming[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased use of fertilisers leading to eutrophication[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased spread of diseases to plantsORanimals due to increased global transport[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased risk of spread of invasive species due to increased global transport[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased spread of pests due to increased air travel damaging agricultureORforest ecosystems[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Rapid human population growth is linked to the current biodiversity crisis because as the global population grows, there is an increased need for resources which can result inloss of habitatdue toincreased agriculture(✓\checkmark✓), an increase in the use offertiliserswhich can result ineutrophication(✓\checkmark✓) and morehuntingof animals (✓\checkmark✓) which lowers animal populations.  An increase in agriculture which utilisesmonocultureslowers species diversity in the area (✓\checkmark✓).  An increase in the human population is also correlated withincreased global transport, which can result in increasedpollution, which contributes toglobal warming(✓\checkmark✓), which can have a detrimental effect on ecosystems and also can result in an increasedspread of invasive species(✓\checkmark✓) andpests(✓\checkmark✓), which lowers biodiversity within ecosystems.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 118
list.content:
Based on the structure of each forelimb shown below, which one is likely to be analogous?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/39606d35-df65-410c-9d8b-ed6f9af2b422/BI0230_A.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/52471306-733f-4dfc-bcae-3f4e8ce6d7de/BI0230_B.png)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/d8fd25b2-43d4-49b1-9f06-91470c27995e/BI0230_C.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a97e321-e9ca-4e8f-8b33-9b3cb18ee915/images/91947f34-f7c5-454c-b802-9fe1906e95f9/BI0230_D.png)

[Adapted from: Source Владислав Петрович , В. (2011).Filevertebrates-en.svg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved June 8, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File.svg copyright freeGraham, V. B. (2016, May 31).File& homologous structures.svg.Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved June 8, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Analogous_%26_Homologous_Structures.svg CC-BY-SA-4.0]
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:An analogous structure is one that has a similar function to other structures but does not come from a common ancestor.Choice Bis a forelimb, but does not have a structure similar to the other three limbs, which indicates that it does not come from a common ancestor, so is likely to be analogous.Choices A,CandDare incorrect as they are all homologous to each other i.e. they share a common ancestor, evidenced by the similarities in their structures.

list.title: Question 119
list.content:
The diagram below shows transcription.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b52a0f7e-44bc-41fb-b520-68f9f818e40a/images/7788d2fb-8bfa-4572-9a23-2786736e9a6e/BI0039.png)

[© Revision Village 2022. Created with BioRender.com]What do structures X and Y have in common?A.\hspace{1em}Both are made up of phosphate groups, ribose sugar and nitrogenous bases.B.\hspace{1em}Both contain hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine.C.\hspace{1em}Both contain sugar-phosphate bonds between phosphate groups and monosaccharides.D.\hspace{1em}Both have six-carbon monosaccharides in their structure.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Structure X is DNA, and structure Y is RNA. Both structures are made up of phosphate groups, sugars and nitrogenous bases. Both structures contain sugar-phosphate bonds, a type of covalent bond, between phosphate groups and sugars.The sugar in DNA is deoxyribose and the sugar in RNA is ribose (Choice A). The sugar molecule in both DNA and RNA is a pentose sugar which means it has five carbon atoms, not six (Choice D).RNA does not contain thymine (Choice B) and it is single-stranded.

list.title: Question 120
list.content:
Refer to the diagram showing a section of a DNA strand.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cda96db5-d1f8-4821-bfb9-ddd33e4caa82/images/af63cd61-e4b6-436d-853c-27b1cbae8bda/Picture1.png)

[© Revision Village 2025. Created in BioRender.com]Which carbon on the deoxyribose sugar is bonded to the phosphate group in the phosphodiester bond?A.\hspace{1em}Carbon 1'B.\hspace{1em}Carbon 2'C.\hspace{1em}Carbon 3'D.\hspace{1em}Carbon 4'
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cda96db5-d1f8-4821-bfb9-ddd33e4caa82/images/a1f3dc2e-b1f0-4602-a55b-087562538587/ANS.png)

The phosphodiester bond forms between the 3' carbon of the sugar in one nucleotide (which has an –OH group), and the 5' phosphate group of the next nucleotide. So, the 3' carbon is directly involved in forming the bond that links nucleotides within a single strand of DNA or RNA, makingChoice Ccorrect.The 1' carbon of the sugar is the attachment point for the nitrogenous base, not for the phosphate group;Choice Ais incorrect.In deoxyribose, the 2' carbon lacks an –OH group (it has just –H), distinguishing DNA from RNA.  It is not involved in bonding to phosphate, soChoice Bis incorrect.The 4' carbon connects to the 3' carbon and the 5' carbon within the sugar ring, but does not form bonds with the phosphate group;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 121
list.content: The plasma membrane, a structure common to all cells, is primarily composed of a phospholipid bilayer. What is the fundamental reason for this specific lipid arrangement?A.\hspace{1em}To provide a flexible boundary for the cell and a source of stored energy.B.\hspace{1em}To create a rigid barrier impermeable to most substances for protection.C.\hspace{1em}To form a selectively permeable barrier due to the hydrophobic nature of the lipids.D.\hspace{1em}To actively transport molecules using energy from the lipids.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because it accurately describes the plasma membrane as selectively permeable, allowing some things to pass and some not, and this is because the tails of the phospholipids comprising the membrane are hydrophobic.Choice Ais incorrect. While it’s true that the membrane provides a flexible boundary for the cell, it is not a source of energy. If the membrane is broken down to release energy, the boundary of the cell will be destroyed, and the cell will cease to exist.Choice Bis incorrect because the membrane is not rigid or impermeable. It is flexible and partially permeable.Choice Dis incorrect because the energy used to transport molecules across the membrane is typically provided by the hydrolysis of ATP.

list.title: Question 122
list.content: Outline the different uses of karyograms.[3]Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei.[4]Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes.[8]
list.markScheme:
Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndromeORPatau syndromeORKlinefelter syndrome[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missingORif part of a chromosome is missing[1][3 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Karyograms(✓\checkmark✓) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs ofdecreasing length(✓\checkmark✓). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms.
Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biologicalmale or female(✓\checkmark✓). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell.
Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g.Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes,ORone chromosome per typeWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two setsORtwo chromosomes of each type[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one allele for each geneWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomesORany other valid species example[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually gametesWHEREASdiploid cells are usually somatic cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis,WHILEdiploid cells are usually the result of mitosis.[1][4 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Haploid nuclei haveone set of chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes.  For example, inhumans(✓\checkmark✓), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei haveone allele for each gene, (✓\checkmark✓)  whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, onlygametes(✓\checkmark✓)  have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei.Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different typesORdifferent numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​both prokaryoticANDeukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins,WHILEeukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA,WHILEeukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHautosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development,WHILEthe X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is only one pair of sex chromosomes,WHILEthere can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species)[1]→\ce{ -> }​autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length,WHILEtwo sex chromosomes can be different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles,WHILEnon-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes[1][8 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but theydiffer in length(✓\checkmark✓) and in thenumber of genes(✓\checkmark✓) andtype of genes(✓\checkmark✓). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomescontain DNA(✓\checkmark✓). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes areassociated with proteins(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes arelinear(✓\checkmark✓).Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes:Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can bemore than one pair of autosomes(✓\checkmark✓) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs areequal in length(✓\checkmark✓)Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes:Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes fordifferent characteristics(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 123
list.content: Which of the following statements explain why classifying diverging populations as species can be arbitrary?I.Traits may diverge at different rates in different populationsII.Some populations may remain reproductively compatible despite divergenceIII.Morphological changes always occur before genetic differences appearA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because, during speciation, some traits (e.g., behaviour, physiology, morphology) can evolve faster than others. This means two populations might look different but still interbreed, or might appear similar but already be reproductively isolated. Because divergence doesn’t follow a fixed pattern, deciding when to define them as separate species becomes subjective.Statement IIis true because Populations might develop noticeable differences in traits (such as colouration or mating calls), but still produce fertile offspring when they interbreed. According to the biological species concept, they’re technically the same species, but these differences can confuse classification.Statement IIIis false because often, the opposite is true. Genetic differences (mutations, allele frequency changes) may accumulate before any visible morphological change occurs. For example, two populations may look identical but carry distinct genetic markers and be reproductively isolated.Saying morphological change “always” comes first is incorrect and overly simplistic.Choice Ais correct because it includes only the two trueStatements IandII.Choices B, CandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement III.

list.markScheme: Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​(comparison of)Paris japonicaANDHomo sapiensdata support the statement[1]→\ce{ -> }​P. japonicahas fewer chromosomes thanH. sapiensbut has more base pairsORP. japonicahas 40 chromosomes with 150,000 million base pairs whileH. sapienshas 46 chromosomes with 3,000 million base pairs.[1]→\ce{ -> }​(comparison of)E.coli,D. melanogasterandP. japonicaORH. sapiensdata does not support the statement[1]→\ce{ -> }​(because) as the number of chromosomes increases, so does the genome size,ORthe number of base pairs[1][2 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The data shows that for all organisms apart fromParis japonicathat higher chromosome number has a larger genome (greater number of base pairs).Paris japonicahasfewer chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓) thanHomo sapiensbut has alarger genome(✓\checkmark✓).P. japonica(✓\checkmark✓) has 40 chromosomes which are less thanHomo sapiens(✓\checkmark✓) but has 150,000 million base pairs compared to 3,000 million base pairs inHomo sapiens.Anytwoof the following:Supporting the statement:→\ce{ -> }​Escherichia coliis the simplest one-cell organism and has the smallest genome sizeORhas 5 million base pairs compared to more complex multicellular organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​T4 phage is not a living organism and has a smaller genome than any of the living organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​fruit flies are simpler organisms than humans and have a smaller genome[1]Not supporting the statement:→\ce{ -> }​Homo sapiensis considered the most complex organism in the table but does not have the largest genome,ORH. sapienshas 3,000 million base pairs compared to 150,000 inP. japonica.[1]→\ce{ -> }​a larger genome does not necessarily mean that an organism has more genes[1]If only one side of the argument is mentioned (but not both), the maximum mark is one.[2 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The datadoes not fully supportthe statement that more complex organisms have a larger genome.For example,Homo sapiensis the most complex organism in the table but does not have the largest genome (✓\checkmark✓).Paris japonica, a woodland plant, has 150,000 million base pairs compared to 3,000 inHomo sapiens, which does not support the statement that more complex organisms have larger genomes because plants are simpler organisms than humans and achieve bigger genomes mostly due to polyploidy. (✓\checkmark✓)On the other hand,Escherichia coliis the simplest living organism in the table and has the smallest genome size, 5 million base pairs. The other organisms are more complex and have larger genomes, e.g.Homo sapienshas 3,000 million base pairs.  (✓\checkmark✓)  T4 page is not considered to be a living organism. The above statementssupportthe notion that the increased genome size means that the organism is more complex.

list.title: Question 125
list.content: What makes up the genome of all eukaryotes but not prokaryotes?I.\hspace{1.6em}Chromosomes and mitochondrial DNAII.\hspace{1.3em}Chloroplast DNAIII.\hspace{1em}Plasmids and ribosomal DNAA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: ASample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The genome is the whole of the genetic information of an organism. In eukaryotes, chromosomes and mitochondrial DNA (Statement I) make up the genome.Choice Ais correct.Chloroplast DNA is not found in all eukaryotes (Statement II). It is primarily found in plant cells but not animal cells;Statement IIis incorrect. Plasmids are found in prokaryotes but not eukaryotes, and ribosomes do not contain DNA,Statement IIIis incorrect.Choices B, CandDare incorrect as they all containStatements IIand/orIII.

list.title: Question 126
list.content: Which breeding practice most directly illustrates artificial selection of a polygenic trait?A.\hspace{1em}Allowing the organisms with traits that fit the environment best to pass them on to the next generation.B.\hspace{1em}Breeding plants which are susceptible to a specific bacteria with those that contain the resistance gene.C.\hspace{1em}Crossing only the tallest wheat plants each generation for an increase in yield.D.\hspace{1em}Introducing wild genes to increase genetic diversity in a breed.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because artificial selection on a polygenic trait involves humans selecting individuals with desirable values for a trait that shows continuous variation, such as plant height, which is typically controlled by multiple genes. By repeatedly crossing the tallest wheat plants, breeders shift the population’s average height upwards over successive generations.Choice Ais incorrect because it describes natural selection, where environmental pressures—not human choice—determine which traits are passed on. In this scenario, humans are letting the environment dictate which individuals breed more successfully, so it is not an example of artificial selection.Choice Bis incorrect because crossing a disease-resistant plant with those that are susceptible to the disease is an example of artificial selection, but not on a polygenic trait, as it only involves one gene.Choice Dis incorrect because introducing wild genes to increase genetic diversity adds variation to the gene pool, but does not involve selecting for a specific trait.

list.title: Question 127
list.content:
The image shows Aotearoa’s (New Zealand) North Island giant moa (Dinornis novaezealandiae), which became extinct in the period 1300 - 1500 A.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2461d794-139c-4be6-9943-c8e721f7962d/images/dcbe8b52-91ed-4354-94f8-f2cd1432bb00/BI2809.png)

[Source: Adapted from Frederick William Frohawk (16 July 1861 - 10 December 1946). File:Dinornis novaezealandiae[image]. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 2025 April 30 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File.png. Public domain]Which of the following factors wasnota contributing factor to the extinction of the giant moa during that period?A.\hspace{1em}Habitat loss caused by human encroachmentB.\hspace{1em}Anthropogenic climate changeC.\hspace{1em}HuntingD.\hspace{1em}Predation by non-human species
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct (not a factor in the moa’s extinction) because this is an example of anthropogenic extinction, but not a direct result of climate change. In the period 1300-1500 A.D., human-caused climate change had not yet occurred; such climate changes began to occur in the mid-20th century and have continued to the present.Choice Ais incorrect (a factor in the moa’s extinction) because human forest clearance would have taken place to create living and farming space for humans, their crops and livestock. This will have reduced the moa’s habitat area, impacting its population.Choice Cis incorrect (a factor in the moa’s extinction) hunting by humans was the single largest factor impacting the moa’s population. They were hunted mainly as a food source for the early settlers of Aotearoa.Choice Dis incorrect (a factor in the moa’s extinction) because the moa was not an apex predator; the Haast’s eagle (Hieraaetus moorei) was a natural predator of the moa, so it played a role in reducing the moa’s population size.

list.title: Question 128
list.content: Which of the following features of DNA most directly underpins its virtually limitless capacity to encode genetic information?A.\hspace{1em}The use of four chemically distinct nitrogenous bases arranged in long chains.B.\hspace{1em}Semiconservative replication via complementary base pairing, which preserves sequence diversity.C.\hspace{1em}The covalent sugar-phosphate backbone’s antiparallel orientation, which fixes strand directionality.D.\hspace{1em}Coiling of DNA into chromosomes, which aids efficient storage.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the linear sequence of four different nucleotides (A, T, C and G) joined by phosphodiester bonds can form an almost infinite number of unique combinations, providing DNA with its enormous information-storage capacity. The human genome is about 3,000,000,000 nucleotides long, so there would be**43,000,000,000\mathbf{4^{3,000,000,000}}43,000,000,000theoretical combinations of nucleotides.Choice Bis incorrect because complementary base pairing ensures faithful replication, but does not itself generate new sequences.Choice Cis incorrect because the antiparallel backbone ensures the strands are arranged in opposite directions, but does not contribute to the sequence diversity.Choice Dis incorrect because coiling allows DNA to be compacted and stored efficiently within the nucleus, but it does not directly contribute to thecapacityto encode genetic information. While necessary for packaging long DNA molecules, coiling does not influence the number of unique sequences that DNA can carry or its ability to store diverse instructions.

list.title: Question 129
list.content: Which of the following isnota real-life example of adhesion?A.\hspace{1em}Surface tension on the surface of a lakeB.\hspace{1em}Dew drops hanging off the tip of a blade of grassC.\hspace{1em}Water coating the surface of the alveoliD.\hspace{1em}Water sticking to cellulose in cell walls
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Surface tension on the surface of the lake, describes the property of cohesion, the ability of water molecules to form hydrogen bonds with other water molecules.Choice Ais correct.Adhesion is the ability of water to form hydrogen bonds with other polar molecules.Choices B, CandDare incorrect as they are all examples of water is sticking to surfaces that are not water molecules, demonstrating adhesion.

list.title: Question 130
list.content: Which of the following best describes an analogous structure?A.\hspace{1em}A structure in two different species that serves a similar function and was inherited from a common ancestor.B.\hspace{1em}A structure in two different species that serves a similar function but evolved independently, without a common ancestor.C.\hspace{1em}A structure found in all members of a species that performs the same function.D.\hspace{1em}A structure found in all members of a species but serves different functions.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Analogous structures are traits found in different species that perform similar functions but do not originate from a common ancestor. Instead, they arise through convergent evolution, where species adapt to similar environments or ecological roles independently.Choice Bis correct as it describes analogous structures, which evolve due to similar selective pressures rather than shared ancestry.Choice Ais incorrect because it describes homologous structures, which share a common evolutionary origin but may have different functions (e.g., a whale's flipper and a human's arm).Choice Cis incorrect because this refers to universal structures within a species, which is unrelated to analogous structures.Choice Dis incorrect because this describes structural variation within a species, not similarities between different species.

list.title: Question 131
list.content: The table below presents observations made about four newly discovered entities (W, X, Y and Z).EntityObservationWContains a cell wall, cytoplasm, and genetic material, but no internal compartments.XConsists of a protein coat surrounding RNA.YContains membrane-bound compartments, each containing DNA.ZExists as free-floating DNA molecules in a liquid medium.Based on cell theory, which row of the table below correctly identifies whether each entity is likely to be classified as a living organism?Entity WEntity XEntity YEntity ZA.\hspace{1em}YesNoYesNoB.\hspace{1em}NoYesNoYesC.\hspace{1em}YesNoNoYesD.\hspace{1em}NoYesYesNo
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Entity W, with a cell wall, cytoplasm, and genetic material, strongly indicates that it is a cell, the basic unit of life. It is likely a prokaryotic cell.Entity Xis only reported to have RNA with a protein coat surrounding it. This description best matches that of a virus. Viruses are not considered living organisms.Entity Ycontains membrane-bound compartments, which are indicative of eukaryotic organelles and DNA. This description is likely describing a eukaryotic cell.Entity Zis only DNA without any barrier to the outside and does not describe a cell.Choice Ais correct because it correctly identifiesEntities WandYas likely to be classified as living, whileXandZ are classifiedas non-living.Choice B, Choice C, andChoice Ddo not have this combination of entities.

list.title: Question 132
list.content: Outline the features of cells that do not conform to the cell theory.[3]Use named species to explain how unicellular organisms carry out processes of life.[4]Compare and contrast the structure of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.[8]
list.markScheme: Anythreefrom the following:→\ce{ -> }​mature red blood cells do not have a nucleus[1]→\ce{ -> }​striated muscle cells have many nuclei[1]→\ce{ -> }​giant algal cells can be seen without a microscopeORgiant algal cells are very large[1]→\ce{ -> }​aseptate fungal hyphaeORfungal hyphaeORMucorare multinucleate[1]→\ce{ -> }​phloem sieve tube elements lack nucleiORdo not have many organellesORhave continuous cytoplasm flowing through adjacent cellsORhave sieve tube elements to provide metabolic supportORare interconnected cells.[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Mature red blood cellsdo not have a nucleus(✓\checkmark✓), mature sieve tube elementsdo not have a nucleus(✓\checkmark✓) and striated muscle cells and fungal hyphae havemany nuclei(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following characteristics and a correct way the chosen unicellular organism carries out that process:→\ce{ -> }​cilia allow movement inParameciumORflagella allow movement inChlamydomonasORany other suitable mode of movement relevant to a named unicellular organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​contractile vacuole helps to regulate water potential of the cellORcontractile vacuole has a role in homeostasis inParameciumORcontractile vacuole helps to regulate water potential of the cellORcontractile vacuole has a role in homeostasis inChlamydomonasORany other mechanism of homeostasis that is relevant to a named unicellular organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​oral groove allows nutrition inParameciumORnutrition is by photosynthesis inChlamydomonasORcorrect mode of nutrition for a named unicellular organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​Parameciumcan reproduce asexually by binary fissionORParameciumcan reproduce by conjugationORChlorellaproduce asexually by mitosis[1]→\ce{ -> }​anal groove allows excretion inParameciumORexcretion is by contractile vacuoles inChlamydomonasORcorrect mode of excretion for a named unicellular organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​growth ofParameciumoccurs after cell divisionORChlamydomonasgrows before and after cell divisionORcorrect mode of growth for a named unicellular organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​Parameciumsense their environment and respond by movement due to the movement of ciliaORChlamydomonashave an eyespot to detect lightORcorrect example of sensitivity for a named unicellular organism[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Parameciaare unicellular organisms that can carry out all functions of life.Parameciahavecilia that allow movement(✓\checkmark✓).Metabolic reactions(✓\checkmark✓) happen in mitochondria and the cytoplasm. The contractile vacuole helps toregulate the water concentration(✓\checkmark✓) ofParameciumby releasing excess water. The oral groove takes in food, so it is responsible fornutrition(✓\checkmark✓).Anyeightof the following:Answermustinclude at least one similarity and one differenceSimilarities:→\ce{ -> }​prokaryoticANDeukaryotic cells have plasma membranes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryoticANDeukaryotic cells have cytoplasm[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryoticANDeukaryotic cells have ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryoticANDeukaryotic cells have genetic materialORDNAORRNA[1]Differences:→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells are not compartmentalisedBUTeukaryotic cells are compartmentalised[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells do not have membrane-bound organellesBUTeukaryotic cells do have membrane-bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have DNA in a loopORplasmidBUTeukaryotes have linear DNAORchromosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells have 70S ribosomesBUTeukaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells do not have a true nucleusORhave a nucleoid regionBUTeukaryotic cells do have a true nucleus[1]→\ce{ -> }​all prokaryotic cells have a cell wallBUTnot all eukaryotic cells have a cell wall[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic DNA is nakedORnot associated with proteinsBUTeukaryotic DNA is associated with histone proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic cells are smallerTHANeukaryotic cells[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells havegenetic material(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells haveplasma membranes(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells havecytoplasm(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells haveribosomes(✓\checkmark✓), butprokaryotes have 70S ribosomes, whereas eukaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic cellsdo not have a true nucleus, but eukaryotic cells do have a true nucleus (✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic cells do not have membrane-bound organelles buteukaryotic cells do have membrane-bound organellessuch as mitochondria (✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic cells haveDNA in a loopbut eukaryotic cells have linear DNA (✓\checkmark✓). Not all eukaryotic cells have a cell wall butall prokaryotic cells do have a cell wall(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 133
list.content:
Which pair of structures would be considered analogous?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7166516d-959c-43cd-ac6f-8b646c6bcc04/images/b41d5e40-835b-4b46-8022-7f52ad7a8980/BI1154.png)

[© Revision Village 2023. Created with BioRender.com]
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Analogous structures refer to structures found in different species which serve a similar function, but are not the result of common ancestry. Sharks are cartilaginous fish, and their fins are modified pectoral fins made of cartilage. Whales are mammals, and their fins are modified forelimbs, which are homologous to the forelimbs of land-dwelling mammals. Whale and shark fins serve the same purpose, are similar in structure, and are the product of convergent evolution.The structures inChoices AandBshare similar functions, but they also share a common ancestry, making them homologous, not analogous.Choice Ccannot be correct as they share a common ancestry but are quite different in terms of structure and function, also making them homologous.

list.title: Question 134
list.content: Palisade mesophyll cells produce and release large amounts of carbohydrates. Which characteristics would you expect to observe in such cells?A.\hspace{1em}A high density of mitochondria and a large central vacuole.B.\hspace{1em}A high density of chloroplasts and an extensive Golgi apparatus.C.\hspace{1em}A high density of chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.D.\hspace{1em}A high density of mitochondria and an extensive Golgi apparatus.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Palisade mesophyll cells are cells in the leaves of plants that produce carbohydrates through photosynthesis. Since photosynthesis takes place within chloroplasts, these cells contain a high density of chloroplasts They also contain a large central vacuole, which occupies the space at the center of the cell and helps maintain the turgor pressure in the cell. The position of the central vacuole ensures the chloroplasts will be pushed near the edges of the cell, where they can receive light. Additionally, the vacuole acts as a storage reservoir for water and other nutrients needed for photosynthesis.Choice AandChoice Dare incorrect because mitochondria are the site of aerobic respiration, during which carbohydrates are broken down to produce ATP.Choice Dis also incorrect as the Golgi apparatus packages proteins, not carbohydrates, for export, soChoice Bis also incorrect.

list.title: Question 135
list.content:
How does introducing new invasive species, such as Japanese knotweed (Reynoutria japonica), to ecosystems affect biodiversity?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7f14db66-6918-4f41-a685-70114e0bcde6/images/01bd4d18-ba7d-4633-965b-1e169e05e1c7/BI0907.png)

[Source: Adapted from Carter, W. (2019, September 11). File: reynoutria japonica in Brastad 1.jpg - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 10, 2023 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Reynoutria_japonica_in_Brastad_1.jpg. Copyright free]A.\hspace{1em}Increases biodiversity because there are more species in the ecosystemB.\hspace{1em}Decreases biodiversity as the invasive species outcompetes native species for resourcesC.\hspace{1em}Decreases biodiversity as new plants encourage new insects and animals to immigrate to the ecosystemD.\hspace{1em}Increases biodiversity as the invasive species brings new pests into the ecosystem
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Invasive species are species that arrive in an ecosystem to which they are not endemic to and they often lack natural population controls such as herbivores or predators.  They therefore sometimes outcompete native species for resources which can decrease biodiversity.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect, as introducing an invasive species usually reduces biodiversity. There are many reasons for this, including competition with native species, predation, herbivory, habitat alteration and the introduction of disease.Choice Cis incorrect as although new plants may encourage new insects and plants to immigrate into an area, this would increase biodiversity, not decrease it.Choice Dis incorrect because although invasive species can bring new pests, these pests often reduce biodiversity by decimating native populations.

list.title: Question 136
list.content: Why is water considered a "universal solvent," and why is this important for the origin of life?I.\hspace{1em}It dissolves a wider variety of substances than any other liquid.II.\hspace{1em}It can dissolve both polar and non-polar molecules.III.\hspace{1em}It enables complex biochemical reactions by facilitating the interaction of reactants.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Water is known as the "universal solvent" because it can dissolve a wider range of substances, than any other liquid (Statement I). This property is due to water's polarity and ability to form hydrogen bonds with various molecules. Water’s ability to dissolve various substances means that it can bring reactants together in a solution, enabling the complex biochemical reactions that are necessary for life (Statement III).Choice Cis correct.Water is a polar solvent, which means it is very effective at dissolving other polar substances and ionic compounds. However, water is not good at dissolving non-polar molecules because there is no attraction between water molecules and non-polar molecules.Statement IIis therefore not true.Choices A, BandDare incorrect as they all includeStatement II.

list.title: Question 137
list.content:
An investigation was carried out into the effects of household detergents on aquatic habitats. Scientists tested the effect of different household detergents on the surface tension of water in order to better understand the impact they may have on organisms living on the surface.A paper clip was folded slightly on one side and rested on the surface of the water, maintained at a constant temperature and contained within a water tank. Drops of detergent solution were slowly added to the water tank until the paperclip sank to the bottom. The volume of detergent solution taken to sink the paperclip was recorded.Detergent solutions were made by adding 5 ml of detergent to 15 ml of water.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/84d7bb7a-360e-4fcc-8359-01fe66042fd4/images/9e71bc21-aad0-4144-8d02-95f90edc6509/BI0769A.png)

[© Revision Village 2022. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]The results are shown in the table.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/84d7bb7a-360e-4fcc-8359-01fe66042fd4/images/f4fd6e73-53ac-412a-9235-7fae1711865e/BI0769B.png)

State the relationship between the volume of detergent solution added and the surface tension of water.[1]For theEasy Cleandetergent, calculate the mean volume of detergent needed to sink the paper clip.[1]Estimate the volume ofEasy Cleandetergent solution it would take to sink 5 paper clips.[1]Stateonevariable, other than those given, which would need to be controlled in this experiment in order to achieve a valid result.[1]Suggestonemethod that could be used to keep the water at a constant temperature.[1]Explain the importance of maintaining water at a constant temperature.[2]Identifyonepotential source of error in the methodology.[1]Suggest why different numbers of drops of detergent solution were needed to sink the paperclip between each type of detergent.[2]

High temperatures can break hydrogen bonds andreduce the cohesive properties(✓\checkmark✓) of water which in turn reduces surface tension.\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​surface tension broken by the droplets of detergent solutionORripples created by droplets of detergent[1]\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​paper clips folded incorrectlyORdifferently (if different paper clips used for each trial)[1]\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​paper clip has residual detergent between trials (if same paper clip is used for each trial)[1]\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​paper clips are different materialsORbrandsORtexture (if different paper clips are used for each trial)[1][1 mark maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}A source of error could be that the surface tension of the water is broken by thedroplets of detergent(✓\checkmark✓) which create ripples. This could result in the paperclip sinking.\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​detergents are made using different chemicalsORdetergents have different starting concentrationsORdifferent concentrations of chemical ingredients[1]\hspace{1em}→\ce{ -> }​some chemicalsORdetergents affect the cohesion between water molecules moreANDtherefore reduce surface tension more[1][2 marks maximum]\hspace{1em}Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:\hspace{1em}There may be a difference between results because each detergent is a different brand which may be made usingdifferent chemicals(✓\checkmark✓). list.title: Question 138
list.content:
Electron microscopes allow the ultrastructure of cells and molecules to be viewed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8564a2e7-66e0-439e-833c-7a0231698c9e/images/76aa3366-9f58-474e-b864-27e972cea989/Edit.png)

[Source: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)/NIH (2019, January 4).Electron micrograph of tau clusters (46603522841).jpg. Wikimedia. Retrieved December 27, 2024, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_micrograph_of_tau_clusters_(46603522841).jpg. Public Domain]Which of these methods is used to analyse protein structure?A.\hspace{1em}Freeze-fracture electron microscopyB.\hspace{1em}Fluorescent stainingC.\hspace{1em}Cryogenic electron microscopyD.\hspace{1em}Immunofluorescence
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because cryogenic electron microscopy can produce 3D images of biological molecules such as proteins, DNA, and RNA. Samples are rapidly frozen to preserve their natural state before an electron beam is passed through, allowing the structure of individual molecules to be studied.Choice Ais incorrect because freeze-fracture electron microscopy is primarily used to study cellular structures, such as the internal arrangement of membranes. While it involves rapid freezing and can produce 3D images, it does not resolve molecular or atomic details of protein structures.Choice Bis incorrect because fluorescent staining is used in light microscopy to identify specific molecules, such as proteins, in cells. Fluorescent dyes or antibodies emit specific wavelengths of light, highlighting target molecules, but they do not provide detailed structural information about proteins.Choice Dis incorrect because immunofluorescence identifies specific proteins in cells or tissues using fluorescently tagged antibodies. While it is useful for locating proteins, it is not a technique for analysing protein structure at the molecular level.

list.title: Question 139
list.content: Which of the following provides evidence for evolution through selective breeding?I.Phenotypic variation in the domesticated dog (Canis familiaris) has increased significantly as a result of humans selecting desirable traits.II.Crop yield in domesticated crop plants is significantly greater than their wild relatives.III.Homo sapiensin many parts of the world have alleles that provide resistance to diseases endemic to their region.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct becauseStatements IandIIare correct.Statement Isupports the theory of evolution because an increase in phenotypes is a component of the process of evolution.Statement IIsupports the theory of evolution because it exemplifies that humans, selecting for desirable traits, can cause directional selection in crop plants.AlthoughStatement IIIdoes support the theory of evolution, it does not do so as an example of selective breeding.  Humans have not been selectively bred.Choices B, CandDdo not exclusively includeStatements I and II, so they are incorrect.

list.title: Question 141
list.content: Which species are prioritised for conservation in the EDGE of Existence programme?A.\hspace{1em}Species that are genetically distinct from other living species, and are in danger of extinction.B.\hspace{1em}Species that are evolutionarily distinct, and are found in vulnerable ecosystems.C.\hspace{1em}Species that are closely related to keystone species, and are in danger of extinction.D.\hspace{1em}Species that are keystone species, and are found in vulnerable ecosystems.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the EDGE of Existence program highlights and focuses on species that are evolutionarily distinct with few living relatives and, therefore, represent a disproportionately high level of genetic diversity. Additionally, the EDGE of Existence program only prioritises species on the endangered and vulnerable IUCN lists, which are, therefore, in danger of extinction.Choice Bis incorrect because the EDGE of Existence program does not use vulnerable ecosystems as a criterion. It focuses solely on species that are evolutionarily distinct and threatened with extinction.Choice Cis incorrect because while keystone species play a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem structure and function, they are not necessarily evolutionarily distinct. The EDGE programme does not prioritise species based on their ecological role.Choice Dis incorrect because neither keystone species nor vulnerable ecosystems are criteria for the EDGE of Existence program.

list.title: Question 142
list.content: The base sequence between two species was found to be 78% the same, while the order of amino acids found in the same cell types between two species was 82% the same.  What may be the reason for this?A.\hspace{1em}The genetic code is degenerate.B.\hspace{1em}Mutations occur more frequently in DNA that codes for proteins.C.\hspace{1em}Techniques used to analyse base sequences of DNA are less reliable.D.\hspace{1em}The genetic code is universal.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because what is meant by “the genetic code is degenerate” is multiple codons sometimes code for the same amino acid, which means that sometimes a mutation will change the genetic code, but the same amino acid is still coded for.Choice Bis incorrect as mutations generally occur more frequently in DNA that does not code for proteins.Choice Cis incorrect as techniques used to analyse the base sequence of DNA are more reliable than those used to determine the order of amino acids.Choice Dis incorrect as the universality of the genetic code refers to the fact that all organisms use the same genetic code.

They also both can havecell walls(✓\checkmark✓), however the cell wall inE.coliis composed ofpeptidoglycan, whereas the cell wall in palisade mesophyll cells is composed ofcellulose(✓\checkmark✓). Palisade mesophyll cells are full ofmembrane boundorganelles such as the golgi apparatus, which gives them acompartmentalisedstructure, whereasE.colido nothave a compartmentalised structure or membrane bound organelles (✓\checkmark✓). Both palisade mesophyll cells andE.colihaveribosomes(✓\checkmark✓), butE.colihave70Sribosomes and palisade mesophyll cells have80Sribosomes  (✓\checkmark✓). DNA is also stored differently in palisade mesophyll cells andE.coli. Palisade mesophyll cells store their DNA inside thenucleusand it has alinearstructure, whereasE.colihave DNA floating freely in the cytoplasm as anucleoid(✓\checkmark✓) and can sometimes contain extra DNA in the form of aplasmid(✓\checkmark✓). E.coli can also have external structures such aspilior flagella (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 144
list.content: Outline three sources which provide evidence for evolution.[3]Describe how both bats and butterflies have wings.[5]Explain the process of speciation with at least one named example.[7]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​DNA sequenceORRNA sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​amino acid sequence of proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​selective breedingORartificial selection[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous structuresORcomparative anatomyORvestigial structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​embryonic development[1]→\ce{ -> }​the fossil record[1]→\ce{ -> }​geographic distribution of species[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Evidence for evolution can come fromDNA sequences(✓\checkmark✓),amino acid sequences(✓\checkmark✓), orhomologous structures(✓\checkmark✓) such as the pentadactyl limb.Anyfiveof the following:→\ce{ -> }​bat wings and butterfly wings  do not share a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​bats share common ancestry with other mammals, whereas butterflies share common ancestry with other insectsORbats are mammalsORMammalia, whereas butterflies are insectsORArthropoda[1]→\ce{ -> }​wings evolved through convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution is the process where unrelated organisms evolve similar characteristicsORtraits to perform similar functions[1]→\ce{ -> }​wings in bats and butterflies are an example of analogous structures[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures share a similar function but are not the result of a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​wings evolved in response to similar environmental pressuresORecological nichesORas a result of natural selection favouring flight[1]→\ce{ -> }​wings in bats are modified forelimbsORare made of skin and boneWHEREASbutterfly wings are notORare made of chitin[1][5 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Bats and butterflies do not share a recentcommon ancestor(✓\checkmark✓), but both evolved wings due toconvergent evolution(✓\checkmark✓). Convergent evolution is the process by which unrelated organisms canevolve similar traitsdue to similar necessities, such as the need to fly (✓\checkmark✓). This means that wings in bats and butterflies are an example ofanalogous structures(✓\checkmark✓) because they share asimilar functionbut do not result from a common ancestor (✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​speciation is the process by which a population is split and evolves differently over time to form distinct species[1]→\ce{ -> }​diversity exists within a populationORgenetic variation exists within a population[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of a population become reproductively isolated[1]→\ce{ -> }​sympatric speciation occurs when new species evolve within the same geographic area[1]→\ce{ -> }​allopatric speciation occurs when new species form in separate geographic areas due to geographical isolation[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolation can be due to geographicalORphysicalORbehaviouralORtemporal barriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​each population is exposed to different environmental conditionsORselective pressures[1]→\ce{ -> }​each population evolves differently over timeORdifferent adaptations evolve over timeORmutations affect each group differentlyORdifferential selectionORgenetic drift affects populations differently[1]→\ce{ -> }​these differences act as barriers to gene flow[1]→\ce{ -> }​over time, the groups evolve differently and can no longer interbreed, so new species have been formed[1]→\ce{ -> }​bonobos and chimpanzeesORany other suitable example of speciation[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Speciation is the process by which a population becomes split, and each group evolves differently over time, leading to the formation ofnew species(✓\checkmark✓). This is possible becausevariationexists within a population (✓\checkmark✓). When a population becomesreproductively isolatedby a geographical barrier like a river (✓\checkmark✓), both groups are exposed to different environmental conditions orselective pressures(✓\checkmark✓). Over time, the two groups evolve differently as different mutations affect both groups, this is referred to asdifferential selection(✓\checkmark✓). These differences between the populations act asbarriers to gene flow(✓\checkmark✓). Over time, the groups evolve so differently that they can no longerinterbreedand are two distinct species (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 148
list.content:
The diagram depicts a single-celled organism living in freshwater that faces water constantly moving into its cell due to osmosis.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5d92e73-ab20-43da-aee4-b427dbf75796/images/c2bb4cec-e54b-4a2c-8f44-13ddf6b20f8d/BI2792.png)

[Source: Adapted fromFile: Paramecium caudatum.svg.(2024, March 12). Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 04:34, April 23, 2025 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File.svg&oldid=859786930.CC Public Domain]To prevent bursting, the cell actively pumps out excess water using specialised structures. This process is an example of:A.\hspace{1em}Obtaining nutrientsB.\hspace{1em}Eliminating waste productsC.\hspace{1em}Responding to external stimuliD.\hspace{1em}Maintaining homeostasis
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Homeostasis is the maintenance of a stable internal environment. The organism pumping out of excess water is a mechanism to keep its osmolarity stable and different from the outside of the cell. Therefore,Choice Dis correct.The organism is not taking in or making any substance for energy and growth, soChoice Ais incorrect.Excess water may be considered a waste product. However, the primary purpose of the pump is to regulate osmolarity and prevent lysis. Waste products typically refer to metabolic wastes like carbon dioxide or nitrogenous compounds. Therefore,Choice Bis incorrect.The active pumping out of water is the organism's way of maintaining internal conditions rather than just a direct response to the stimulus, and soChoice Cis incorrect.

list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because there are 23 chromosomes, so it is a haploid cell, and one of the sex chromosomes is the ‘Y’ chromosome.  Egg cells do not have the Y chromosome.Choice Bis incorrect because all egg cells have one ‘X’ sex chromosome.Choice Candchoice Dare incorrect because skin and brain cells are diploid, so they have two of each chromosome: 46 in total.

list.title: Question 150
list.content:
What bases are P, Q, and R if S is a pyrimidine?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f497fb1a-2df4-4043-a760-f2d78e9bc76a/images/3b6c2a4e-8c5c-4c00-a882-93d69b4c4568/BI0897A.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]PQRA.\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Guanine\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Cytosine\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Thymine\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}GuanineAdenineCytosineC.\hspace{1em}CytosineGuanineAdenineD.\hspace{1em}AdenineThymineCytosine
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Adenine and guanine are purines. Cytosine and thymine are pyrimidines.If S is a pyrimidine (~20%), it is either cytosine or thymine. Purines pair with pyrimidines, so Q, which also makes up about 20% of the molecule, must be guanine or adenine. This meansChoices AandDcan be eliminated as correct answers.P and R must pair up as they make up approximately the same proportion of the DNA. So P and R must either be adenine and thymine or guanine and cytosine. This meansChoice Cis incorrect.This leaves us with the correct answer ofChoice B.  P is guanine, which pairs with R, cytosine, and Q is adenine, which pairs with S, which must be thymine.

need to conduct surveys onspecies diversity in the area over time. (✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​maintain food chainsORwebs[1]→\ce{ -> }​trees carry out carbon captureORrelease oxygen into the atmosphereORclimate change mitigation[1]→\ce{ -> }​prevent extinction of organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​promote tourism in the areaORaesthetic reasons[1]→\ce{ -> }​slow down the spread of zoonotic diseases (as loss of habitat means that animals will live }​prevents floodsORlandslides due to increased transpiration[1]→\ce{ -> }​provides more food for organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​encourages the establishment of complex ecological interactionsORan example such as an increase in number of pollinators for plant reproduction[1]→\ce{ -> }​increases species richness[1]→\ce{ -> }​increases genetic diversityORgene flow[1]Decrease biodiversity because...→\ce{ -> list.title: Question 153
list.content: The table shows factors that can result in speciation. Which word is matched to the correct definition?WordDefinitionA.\hspace{1em}PolyploidyHaving two complete sets of chromosomesB.\hspace{1em}Sexual reproductionThe combining of genetic information from two individualsC.\hspace{1em}Reproductive isolationSpecies breeding to produce infertile offspringD.\hspace{1em}MutationsRandom changes to the amino acid sequence
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of gametes from two individuals, resulting in offspring with a combination of genetic material. This process increases genetic variation, which is essential for evolution and natural selection.Choice Bis the correct answer.Polyploidy occurs when an organism has more than two complete sets of chromosomes (e.g., triploid 3n, tetraploid 4n). The definition given in the table describes diploidy (2n), which is the standard chromosome number in most sexually reproducing organisms;Choice Aincorrect.Interbreeding between different species can sometimes produce infertile offspring, such as a horse × donkey = mule. This is an example of reproductive isolation because the hybrid offspring is sterile, preventing gene flow between the two species. However, because horses and donkeys are already separate species, this does not result in speciation—it simply reinforces their reproductive barrier. For reproductive isolation to lead to speciation, it must occur within a single species, preventing interbreeding between different populations.Choice Cis incorrect.Mutations are random changes in DNA sequences, not in the amino acid sequence;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 154
list.content: Outline the role of the active site in an enzyme.[3]Outline how members of the same species can become separate populations via speciation.[4]Describe the regulation and use of hormones during in vitro fertilisation (IVF).[8]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​it is the binding site for a substrateORspecific region where the substrate binds[1]→\ce{ -> }​it allows for induced fit binding of the substrate[1]→\ce{ -> }​it facilitates enzyme-substrate specificityORhas a specific shape that allows the substrate to bind effectively[1]→\ce{ -> }​it causes a conformational change in the enzyme-substrate complex, which leads to the formation of products[1]→\ce{ -> }​it is the site where a substrate is converted into a productORwhere a substrate is held while a chemical reaction takes place[1]→\ce{ -> }​it lowers the energy of the transition stateORactivation energy so that a chemical reaction can take place more efficiently[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The active site of an enzyme is a specific region where asubstrate binds(✓\checkmark✓). Within the active site, the enzymelowerstheenergy of the transition state(✓\checkmark✓), facilitating the chemical reaction so that the substrate can be successfullyconverted into a product(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​a population consists of all organisms of one species living in the same place at the same time, capable of breeding together[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of the species can become geographically isolatedORseparated by a physical barrier such as a riverORmountain[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of the species can become temporally isolatedORbecome separated by producing gametes at different timesORseasons[1]→\ce{ -> }​members of the species can become behaviourally isolatedORbecome separated by displaying distinctive courtship behaviours[1]→\ce{ -> }​when populations of the same species become separated, genetic drift will cause the allele frequencies to change[1]→\ce{ -> }​reproductive isolation mechanisms, such as incompatibility of reproductive organs, can prevent interbreeding between separated populations[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations can introduce new genetic variations in each isolated population, contributing to genetic divergence over time[1]→\ce{ -> }​selective pressures will act on the separated species, leading to an accumulation of genetic differences in each populationORnatural selection will act on each population so that traits that are beneficial to each group will accumulate[1]→\ce{ -> }​over many generations, speciation will occurORthe separate populations will not be able to breed to produce fertile offspring[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Members of the same species can become separate populations if they becomegeographically isolated(✓\checkmark✓) orbehaviourally isolated(✓\checkmark✓). Once populations of the same species are separated,genetic driftwill cause theallele frequencies to change(✓\checkmark✓).Selective pressureswill act on the separated populations, leading to anaccumulation of genetic differences(✓\checkmark✓). Eventually,speciation(✓\checkmark✓) will occur, resulting in populations that can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring.anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​drugs are used to downregulate several hormonesORFSHORfollicle stimulating hormone AND LHORluteinising hormone, to better control the releaseORmaturation of follicles later on[1]→\ce{ -> }​the function of FSHORfollicle-stimulating hormone is to promote follicle growthORmature eggs[1]→\ce{ -> }​the function of LHORluteinising hormone is to trigger ovulationORtrigger the release of mature eggs from the ovaries[1]→\ce{ -> }​the downregulation of LH and FSH also results in the downregulation of oestrogen and progesterone[1]→\ce{ -> }​oestrogen normally stimulates the uterineORendometrial lining to build up[1]→\ce{ -> }​progesterone normally stimulates the maintenance of the uterineORendometrial lining for implantation[1]→\ce{ -> }​high doses of FSH are injected to stimulate superovulationORthe development of many follicles[1]→\ce{ -> }​the development of many follicles increases the chances of successful fertilisation during the IVF process[1]→\ce{ -> }​gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are injected to prevent premature ovulationORcontrol the timing of ovulation[1]→\ce{ -> }​human chorionic gonadotropinORhCG is injected to stimulate the follicles to mature[1]→\ce{ -> }​progesterone is injected before the fertilised egg is implanted to improve the chances of successful implantation[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is a process used by couples with fertility issues, where mature eggs are fertilised outside the body. To start the process,drugsare used todownregulate several reproductive hormonesto better control therelease and maturation of follicleslater on (✓\checkmark✓). The downregulation ofFSH stops follicles from growing(✓\checkmark✓). Drugs are also used todownregulate LH, which results in theprevention of ovulation(✓\checkmark✓). The downregulation of LH and FSH also results in thedownregulationofoestrogen and progesterone(✓\checkmark✓), which normally function to stimulate thebuild-up of the uterine lining(✓\checkmark✓) andmaintain the uterine lining(✓\checkmark✓), respectively. Once these hormones are successfully downregulated,high doses of FSHare injected to trigger thedevelopment of multiple folliclesin the ovary(✓\checkmark✓). The development of many folliclesincreases the chance of successful fertilisationduring the IVF process (✓\checkmark✓).GnRH agonistsare injected toprevent premature ovulation(✓\checkmark✓), andhCGis injected to stimulate thefollicles to mature(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.

list.title: Question 155
list.content:
Mountain gorillas (Gorilla beringei beringei)  were reclassified from "Critically Endangered" to "Endangered" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) in November 2018. This change in status was a significant conservation success story, reflecting the positive impact of concerted efforts by governments, conservation organisations, and local communities to protect and increase the population of this subspecies of the eastern gorilla.
The table below shows the changes in the number of mountain gorillas from 2010 to 2018.YearNumber of gorillas2010480201660420181004Calculate the percentage increase in the number of gorillas from 2010 to 2018.[1]Although the mountain gorilla is rarely seen in zoos, another gorilla subspecies, the western lowland gorilla (Gorilla gorilla gorilla) is. Explain how zoos play a critical role in the conservation of endangered species.[3]Studies have shown that the invasive plant speciesSericostachys scandensaffects forest composition and may affect the Grauer’s gorilla (Gorilla beringei graueri) recovery in Congo.Outline two precautions that should be taken before considering biological control of invasive plants such as these.[2]
list.markScheme:

, ensuring it can effectively reduce the invasive populationwithout becoming invasiveitself(✓\checkmark✓).
