list.title: Question 181
list.content:
The Eurasian beaver (Castor fiber) has been described as a species that promotes biodiversity. Beavers are herbivores that feed on freshwater plants and tree bark. They use their sharp front teeth to fell trees and use the logs and branches to build dams that create pools in which they can build their lodge. A beaver lodge is a construction in which they nest and raise their young, providing protection from predators.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/0716c3a5-4515-4c2c-9098-2dc170bfb110/BI1684%20fig1.png)

[Source: Jerzy Strzelecki, retrieved July 2024 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Castor_fiber_07(js),_Narew_River,
_Poland.jpg, copyright under CC BY-SA 3.0]Suggest ways in which the reintroduction of beavers can increase biodiversity.[4]The effect of introducing beavers on the species diversity of birds and bats was studied in four areas: on river banks, one without any beaver activity and one where beavers are present, and then ponds, again, one without beaver activity and one where beavers were present. The graph below shows the calculated Simpson’s reciprocal index of Diversity for each area.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/536e088c-9e87-4ae5-902d-c81de6be0cb0/BI1684%20fig2.png)

[©Revision Village 2024]State two necessary measurements to calculate Simpson’s reciprocal index of diversity.[1]Calculate the percentage increase in the species diversity of bats in the pond after the introduction of the beaver.[2]Beavers became extinct in the UK over 400 years ago. Reintroduction programmes are now being carried out in various regions of the UK.Suggestthreeanthropogenic activities that could have led to the extinction of the beavers in the UK.[3]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​many different habitatsORniches are created by beaver activity[1]→\ce{ -> }​dams create pools that slow the run-off of rivers, benefiting plant rooting[1]→\ce{ -> }​dams generate wetlands that harbour insectORinvertebrate species[1]→\ce{ -> }​this promotes a food chain with consumers such as birds[1]→\ce{ -> }​pools are habitats for aquatic plantsORfish[1]→\ce{ -> }​felling trees allows sunlight onto the forest floor, benefiting ground-level plants and shrubs[1]→\ce{ -> }​fallen trees are a source of food for microorganismsORdetritivores[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The activity of beaverscreates many habitatsfor other organisms (✓\checkmark✓), with an overall increase in biodiversity. For example, the felling of trees opens up patches of ground to sunlight,promoting ground-level vegetation(✓\checkmark✓). The pools created by beaver damsattract insects(✓\checkmark✓) and the consumers (such as birds) thatfeed on those insects(✓\checkmark✓). Dams slow the run-off of rainwater which has abeneficial effect on plant rootswhich are not washed away by fast-flowing water (✓\checkmark✓). The pools also attractfish species and aquatic plantsthat can oxygenate the pond water (✓\checkmark✓); beavers do not eat fish, so there is no harm to the fish from them.the following:→\ce{ -> }​total number of different species in the areaORspecies richnessANDtotal number of organisms of each speciesORspecies evenness[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Two measurements needed to calculate Simpson’s Diversity Index are thetotal number of species in the areaand thetotal number of organisms of each species(✓\checkmark✓).the following:→\ce{ -> }​percentage increase = {(final volume - initial volume)/initial volume}×\times×100%[1]OR{(0.81-0.51) / 0.51}×\times×100%→\ce{ -> }​58.8%   (allow numbers between 52 and 64%)[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Percentage increase ={(p.81−-−0.51) / 0.51} x 100%(✓\checkmark✓)=−-−58.8%(✓\checkmark✓)anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​hunting for furORcastoreum[1]→\ce{ -> }​habitat destructionORthe draining of wetlandsORother hydrological changes[1]→\ce{ -> }​deforestationORloggingORincrease in agricultural land[1]→\ce{ -> }​water pollution[1]→\ce{ -> }​fragmentation of landscape[1]→\ce{ -> }​urbanisationORindustrial developmentORroad construction[1]→\ce{ -> }​introduction of alien species[1]→\ce{ -> }​tradeORtravel leading to introduction of disease[1]→\ce{ -> }​use of pesticidesORherbicidesORagricultural chemicals[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The extinction of beavers in the UK may have been caused byoverhuntingfor their valuablefurandcastoreum(✓\checkmark✓), combined withextensive habitat destructiondue to thedraining of wetlands(✓\checkmark✓) anddeforestationforagricultural expansion(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, theintroduction of non-native species(✓\checkmark✓) anddiseases, through internationaltravel, (✓\checkmark✓) further contributed to their decline.

list.title: Question 182
list.content: A student, learning to use a microscope, observed a pollen grain under a microscope with a magnification of ×100. Using an eyepiece graticule, they measured the diameter of the pollen grain to be 25 divisions. At this magnification, 1 division on the eyepiece graticule equals 3μ\muμm. To allow the student to measure more pollen grains and to calculate a mean diameter, which of the following conclusions on the experimental work so far is/are correct?I.\hspace{1em}Increasing the magnification of the objective lens would widen the field of view.II.\hspace{.7em}The actual diameter of the pollen grain is 75μ\muμm.III.\hspace{.5em}If the magnification were increased to ×200, each eyepiece graticule division would represent a smaller actual size.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis not true. Increasing the magnification will narrow the field of view. This is a common student mistake. As magnification increases, the observer is focusing on a smaller area, like zooming in with a camera.Statement IIis true. The actual diameter of the pollen grain is calculated as 25 divisions × 3 µm/division = 75 µm.Statement IIIis true. If the magnification were increased by switching to a higher power objective, the same number of eyepiece graticule divisions would span a smaller actual distance on the specimen.Choice Cis correct because it contains the proper combination ofStatement IIandStatement III.Choice A, Choice BandChoice Ddo not contain the proper combination of statements.

list.title: Question 183
list.content: The following table shows the approximate number of protein-encoding genes found in various species. What can be concluded from these findings?SpeciesApproximate number of protein-encoding genesDrosophila melanogaster(fruit fly)14,000Oryza sativa(rice)51,000Gallus gallus(chicken)20,000-23,000Homo sapiens(human)20,000-25,000I.The number of genes is not a good indicator of organism complexity.II.Chickens may have more genes than humans.III.The number of base pairs in the rice genome is greater than in the other species.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The number of genes found in a species does not serve as a good indicator of complexity (Statement I). If it did, the data here would suggest that chickens and humans are equally complex, and that rice is far more complex than either of them. Due to the overlapping ranges in the number of genes, it is entirely possible for chickens to have a greater number of genes than humans (Statement II). It is impossible to determine the size of the genome (measured in base pairs) of a species based on the number of genes it has. In reality, rice has far fewer base pairs than chickens or humans despite having approximately twice as many genes (Statement III).Choice Ais, therefore, correct.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect as they all containStatement III.

list.title: Question 184
list.content: Outline the binomial naming system and its importance.[4]Explain how a sample of cells taken from a foetus can be used to determine whether the foetus will be biologically male or biologically female at birth.[4]Outline the outcomes of the human genome project and their impacts on different fields of science.[7]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​binomial naming system as the system used to name species[1]→\ce{ -> }​genus name and species name[1]→\ce{ -> }​species with the same genus share many characteristicsORare closely related[1]→\ce{ -> }​internationally agreed[1]→\ce{ -> }​facilitates understanding and communication between scientists[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The binomial naming system is the system which scientists use toname species(✓\checkmark✓) and this isinternationally agreed(✓\checkmark✓), which means it’s used all over the world, which aids in thecommunicationbetween scientists (✓\checkmark✓) in different countries. The name of each species has two parts, the first highlights thegenusto which it belongs and the second part refers to thespecies(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​cells grown in a culture medium[1]→\ce{ -> }​cells stained[1]→\ce{ -> }​observed under a light microscope[1]→\ce{ -> }​photomicrograph taken during mitosisORmitotic metaphase[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomes arranged according to sizeORposition of centromeres[1]→\ce{ -> }​look at chromosome pair 23[1]→\ce{ -> }​two large chromosomes mean foetus is XX[1]→\ce{ -> }​one large chromosome and one small chromosome means foetus is XY[1]→\ce{ -> }​XX is biologically femaleANDXY is biologically male[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Once the sample of cells has been taken from the foetus they are grown in aculture medium(✓\checkmark✓). They are thenstained(✓\checkmark✓) and observed under alight microscope(✓\checkmark✓). Aphotomicrographis taken (✓\checkmark✓), and the image is cut up so that thechromosomescan bearranged by sizeand position of thecentromere(✓\checkmark✓). A foetus withtwo large Xchromosomes will bebiologically female(✓\checkmark✓), and a foetus withone large Xandone small Ychromosome will bebiologically male(✓\checkmark✓).Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the Human Genome Project (HGP) sequenced the entire human genome[1]→\ce{ -> }​it determined the total number of base pairs in the human genome[1]→\ce{ -> }​it estimated the number of genes in the human genome[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified the loci of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified repeat sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified locations of single nucleotide polymorphisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​identified gene sequences associated with certain diseasesORbiological processesORtraits[1]→\ce{ -> }​HGP stimulated further developmentORreduced the price of sequencing technology[1]→\ce{ -> }​technology developed for the HGP is now used to diagnose diseasesORidentify micro-organisms OR DNA matching in forensics and medicineORgenetic modification[1]→\ce{ -> }​contributed to the field by identifying genetic markers that affect how individuals metabolise and respond to medicationsORcontribute information for personalised medicine[1]→\ce{ -> }​insights into evolutionary relationshipsORgenetic similaritiesORgenetic differences[1]→\ce{ -> }​identification of regulatory elementsORnon-coding RNAsORcomponents that play essential roles in gene expressionORcellular function[1]→\ce{ -> }​emphasised importance of consideration of ethicalORlegalORsocial implications of genomic research[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The Human Genome Project (HGP)sequencedthe entire human genome (✓\checkmark✓),identified the lociof genes (✓\checkmark✓) and identified gene sequences that are connected to somediseases(✓\checkmark✓) such as breast cancer. Locations ofsingle nucleotide polymorphisms(✓\checkmark✓) were discovered which are variations in individuals DNA base pairs. The results have contributed to the development ofpersonalised medicine(✓\checkmark✓) as genetic markers have been identified that affect how individuals respond to medications. The technology developed for the HGP has led to further advancements in technology,reducing the costof genetic sequencing (✓\checkmark✓).  The HGP also emphasised how important it is to consider theethical implications(✓\checkmark✓) of genomic research and the importance of informed consent.A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 185
list.content: Which organelle is formed by a vesicle derived from the cell membrane?A.\hspace{1em}Food vacuoleB.\hspace{1em}RibosomeC.\hspace{1em}Golgi apparatusD.\hspace{1em}Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When a cell takes in material through endocytosis, it produces a vesicle derived from the cell membrane, which is how a food vacuole is formed.Ribosomes are involved in translation (Choice B), the golgi apparatus sorts, packages and modifies proteins (Choice C) and the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, among other functions, synthesizes lipids (Choice D).

list.title: Question 186
list.content: Which of the following statements explains how water has facilitated the evolution of life on Earth?A.\hspace{1em}Water acts as a catalyst for chemical reactionsB.\hspace{1em}Water acts as a solvent allowing chemical reactions to occur faster within itC.\hspace{1em}Water acts in hydrolysis reactions allowing for the synthesis of large biological moleculesD.\hspace{1em}Water has a high latent heat of vaporisation so is able to convert between states easily
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Water's unique ability to act as a solvent is crucial for life's evolution. Many biochemical reactions that are fundamental to life occur within aqueous environments. Water's solvent properties facilitate the dissolution and interaction of molecules, enabling chemical reactions to occur more rapidly and efficiently.Choice Bis, therefore, correct.Water acts as a reaction medium for many chemical reactions, but does not catalyse the chemical reactions that facilitate evolution,Choice Ais incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect as hydrolysis reactions break down larger molecules into smaller ones.Choice Dis incorrect as water’s high latent heat of vaporisation means that it requires a lot of energy to convert liquid water into a gas.

list.title: Question 187
list.content: Which row in the table is correct for either the biological or morphological species concept?ConceptSpecies DefinitionProposed by…A.\hspace{1em}BiologicalA group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspringLinnaeusB.\hspace{1em}BiologicalA group of organisms with shared traitsMayrC.\hspace{1em}MorphologicalA group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspringMayrD.\hspace{1em}MorphologicalA group of organisms with shared traitsLinnaeus
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The morphological concept refers to a species as a group of organisms with shared traits. It assumes that individuals that look alike are part of the same species. This was proposed by Linnaeus.Choice Dis correct.Choice Ais incorrect because although the definition of the biological species concept is correct, it was not proposed by Linnaeus, it was proposed by Mayr.Choices BandCare incorrect because neither the definitions nor the proposers are correct.

list.title: Question 188
list.content:
The graph shows the global human population since 1700 CE, with a projection made to 2086.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/5e38479b-021b-42bf-9f22-5749b575d27f/QuesEdit2.png)

[© Revision Village 2025]According to the projection, what will be the percentage population increase between 2000 and 2050 CE?A.\hspace{1em}27%B.\hspace{1em}38%C.\hspace{1em}62%D.\hspace{1em}88%
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because the global human population in 2000 was 6.0 billion, projected to increase to 9.7 billion by 2050.The increase is:
9.7 billion − 6.0 billion = 3.7 billionTo calculate the percentage increase:Percentage increase = (increasepopulationin2000)×100\dfrac{\ce{increase}}{\ce{population in 2000}}) \times 100populationin2000increase​)×100%= (3.7billion6.0billion)×100\dfrac{\ce{3.7 billion}}{\ce{6.0 billion}}) \times 1006.0billion3.7billion​)×100% = 61.67%All the choices are stated to 2 significant figures, so rounding this answer to two significant figures gives62%.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/254de718-6f94-46dc-b122-0decdf87d016/AnsEdit2.png)

Choices A, BandDare incorrect because they all contain calculation errors.

list.title: Question 189
list.content: This table shows the estimated number of genes inE. colibacteria, fruit flies, mice, humans, and rice.SpeciesEstimated number of genesE.coli(bacteria species)4,000Drosophila melanogaster(fruit fly)13,000Canis lupis familiaris(dog)20,000Homo sapiens(humans)30,000Oryza sativa(rice)40,000What can you conclude from the above information?A.\hspace{1em}Species in the same kingdom of life have a similar number of genesB.\hspace{1em}Different species have different numbers of genesC.\hspace{1em}More complex species have more genesD.\hspace{1em}The number of genes is not a characteristic of a species
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis the correct answer.  This is a small sample of species, but the process of elimination meansChoice Bis the only possible correct answer. Fruit flies, humans and dogs are all in the animal kingdom but have different numbers of genes (Choice A).  This information shows that the number of genes does not determine the complexity, as rice has more genes than humans (Choice C). It is not possible to conclude that the number of genes is not a characteristic of a species from this small sample of data (Choice D).

list.title: Question 190
list.content: Which of the following statement(s) about the role of water as a solvent is correct?I.Salt can dissolve in water because it is hydrophilicII.Lipids cannot dissolve in water because they are non-polarIII.Cellulose can dissolve in water, as it is able to form hydrogen bondsA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Salt, an ionic compound, dissolves readily in water because water is a polar solvent and can interact with the charged ions in salt through electrostatic attractions. Substances that have an affinity for water and can form interactions with water molecules are referred to as hydrophilic (Statement I). Lipids are non-polar molecules, and water is a polar solvent. Polar and non-polar substances do not readily mix because water molecules are attracted to each other through hydrogen bonding and other dipole-dipole interactions. Lipids are hydrophobic, meaning they repel water and do not dissolve well in it (Statement II).Choice Cis, therefore, correct.Although cellulose can form hydrogen bonds, it is insoluble (Statement III) as it is too large to dissolve in water;Choices BandDare therefore incorrect as they include this statement.Choice Ais incorrect as it does not includestatement II.

list.title: Question 191
list.content: Which statement is true for both Lamarckism and epigenetic inheritance?A.\hspace{1em}Both involve changes in the DNA sequence that are inherited and lead to evolution.B.\hspace{1em}Both involve inherited changes caused by the environment, but the effect of epigenetics may only last a few generations, so it is not a type of evolution.C.\hspace{1em}Both operate by the use and disuse of traits, leading to evolutionary change.D.\hspace{1em}Only epigenetics leads to changes in the DNA sequence and, therefore, evolution.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because both Lamarckism and epigenetic inheritance propose that environmental factors can cause inherited changes, while Lamarckism suggested these changes were permanent and led to evolution through traits acquired during an organism's lifetime. Epigenetic changes involve reversible chemical modifications to DNA or histone proteins that affect gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. These epigenetic changes can be passed to offspring, but often only persist for a few generations and typically do not lead to long-term evolutionary change.Choice Ais incorrect because neither Lamarckism nor epigenetic inheritance involves changes to the DNA sequence itself. Epigenetics modifies gene expression through chemical tags, while Lamarckism assumed physical or behavioural changes were inherited.Choice Cis incorrect because only Lamarckism proposed that the use or disuse of traits directly causes evolutionary change. Epigenetic inheritance does not involve the use or disuse of structures but rather chemical changes to gene regulation influenced by environmental factors. Furthermore, epigenetics does not lead to evolution.Choice Dis incorrect because epigenetic inheritance does not involve changes to the DNA sequence itself and therefore does not cause long-term evolutionary change.

list.title: Question 192
list.content: Organisms that are better adapted to their environment are more likely to survive and thrive.Describe how the skin and mucous membranes provide both physical and chemical defence against pathogens.[4]Explain the importance of concentration gradients and the mechanisms that regulate them in the human ventilation system.[4]Discuss to what extent the fossil record provides evidence for evolution.[7]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:Answer must include one point from physical defence and one point from chemical defence to gain full marksPhysical defence→\ce{ -> }​skin provides a physical barrierORis composed of multiple tissue layers preventing pathogens from entering the body[1]→\ce{ -> }​skin continuously sheds dead cells which removes any pathogens on the surface[1]→\ce{ -> }​cells in skin are held together by tight junctions reinforcing the barrier functionORpreventing pathogens from passing between cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​mucus produced by mucous membranes can trap pathogens[1]→\ce{ -> }​mucus containing trapped pathogens is either expelled by the body or swallowed[1]→\ce{ -> }​cilia on mucous membrane surfaces move pathogensORforeign particles out of the body[1]Chemical defence→\ce{ -> }​sebaceous glands in the skin secrete sebum, which lowers the pH of the skin and inhibits the growth of bacteria and fungi[1]→\ce{ -> }​mucus contains lysozymeORantimicrobial enzymes which break down bacterial cell walls[1]→\ce{ -> }​sweat contains antimicrobialsORacids which inhibit growth of pathogens[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Theskinprovidesphysical defenceby forming abarrierthatprevents pathogensfromenteringthebody(✓\checkmark✓). It also provideschemical defenceagainst pathogens by havingsebaceous glandsthatsecrete sebum, whichlowersthepHof the skin and soinhibitsthegrowthofbacteriaandfungion the skin (✓\checkmark✓). Mucous membranes line the internal surfaces of some organs and body cavities and secrete mucus, which cantrap pathogens(✓\checkmark✓). The mucus is thenexpelledby the body orswallowed(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​steeper the concentration gradient, the greater the rate of diffusion, allowing for faster movement of molecules from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​inhaled air in alveoli has a higher concentration of oxygen than oxygen-depleted blood in the capillaries surrounding the alveoliORblood has a higher concentration of carbon dioxide than the air in the alveoli.[1]→\ce{ -> }​concentration gradients facilitate diffusion of oxygen from alveoli into bloodORcarbon dioxide from blood into alveoli, which provides cells with oxygen for respiration and removes waste carbon dioxide[1]→\ce{ -> }​large network of capillaries surrounding alveoli rapidly transport oxygen away from the lungsORrapidly transport carbon dioxide from the body to the lungs[1]→\ce{ -> }​the processes of inhalation and exhalation ensure that there is a constant flow of air in and out of lungs[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemoreceptors in carotid arteryORaortaORmedulla monitor blood pH levelsORblood carbon dioxide concentrations[1]→\ce{ -> }​chemoreceptors send signals to respiratory centre in medulla oblongata OR brain stem[1]respiratory centreORmedulla oblongata controls breathing rateORdepth of breathing to maintain concentration gradient of oxygen[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Efficient gas exchange in the lungs relies on maintaining concentration gradients, whereinhaled airin thealveolihas ahigher concentrationofoxygenthanoxygen-depleted bloodand alower concentrationofcarbon dioxide than that inthe surroundingcapillaries(✓\checkmark✓). This gradient allowsoxygentodiffuse fromthealveoliinto thebloodandcarbon dioxide fromtheblood intothealveoli(✓\checkmark✓). An extensivenetwork of capillariessurrounding the alveoli rapidlytransports oxygen awayfrom thelungsandcarbon dioxide tothe lungs (✓\checkmark✓). The processes ofinhalationandexhalationensure aconstant flowofairin and out of the lungs,maintainingthesegradients(✓\checkmark✓).Chemoreceptorsin thecarotid arteryandaortamonitorblood pH(✓\checkmark✓), sendingsignals totherespiratory centretoadjust breathing rateanddepth(✓\checkmark✓).Aaysevenof the following:Answer must include one answer from ‘provides evidence’ and one answer from ‘doesn’t provide’ evidence to gain full marksProvides evidence→\ce{ -> }​some organisms have very good fossil records, which allow their evolution to be tracked easily, e.g. horses[1]→\ce{ -> }​the sequence of fossils that appear in layers of rock matches the sequence in which they would be expected to evolve[1]→\ce{ -> }​older organisms appear in deeper rock layersORstrata, and more recently evolved organisms appear in the upper layers[1]→\ce{ -> }​there are fossils of extinct organisms with transitional formsORfossils of extinct organisms that have features that link different stages of evolution, e.g. Archaeopteryx, bird-like dinosaurs that support the hypothesis that birds evolved from reptiles[1]→\ce{ -> }​the fossil record shows evidence of mass extinction eventsORthere are many more extinct species than living ones[1]→\ce{ -> }​fossils show evidence of adaptive radiationORdivergence of different organisms from a common ancestorORspeciation[1]→\ce{ -> }​the fossil record shows evidence of vestigial structures that are no longer present in current organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is fossil evidence for the existence of the last universal common ancestor (LUCA) near hydrothermal vents[1]→\ce{ -> }​fossils provide chronological evidence that supports the theory of gradualism in evolution, where small changes accumulate over long periods[1]→\ce{ -> }​fossilised remains of early hominids show a clear progression in brain sizeORbipedalism, supporting human evolution[1]Doesn’t provide evidence→\ce{ -> }​fossil record is incomplete, with many gapsORsome fossil species appear abruptly in the fossil record without any precursors[1]→\ce{ -> }​some species in the fossil record appear not to have changed much over long periods of time[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolutionORfossils of unrelated organisms with similar features makes it difficult to track evolution accurately[1]→\ce{ -> }​soft-bodied organisms are rarely fossilised, leading to an incomplete record that skews our understanding of evolutionary history[1]→\ce{ -> }​process of fossilisation is rare and biased towards certain environments, meaning that the fossil record may not accurately represent all ecosystems and organisms[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The fossil record supports evolution because some organisms havewell-documented fossil recordsthat allow their evolutionary changes to betracked easily(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, thesequencein whichfossils appear in rock layersmatches the sequence in which they would beexpected to evolve(✓\checkmark✓). For example,olderorganisms are found indeeper layersof rocks, while morerecently evolved organismsare found in theupper layers(✓\checkmark✓). There are also fossils of extinct organisms withtransitional features, such as Archaeopteryx, a bird-like dinosaur, which supports the hypothesis that birds evolved from reptiles and providesevolutionary linksbetween present and extinct species (✓\checkmark✓). However, there aregapsin the fossil record (✓\checkmark✓), some species appear not to havechanged over long periods of time(✓\checkmark✓), andconvergent evolutioncan make it difficult to track evolution accurately (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.

list.title: Question 193
list.content: Which of the following are a reason why water's properties would have influenced early cellular evolution in aquatic environments?I.High surface tension allowing formation of proto-cell membranes.II.Polar solvent properties enabling interaction of biomolecules.III.High density causing rapid sedimentation of organic material.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Water's ability to dissolve biomolecules and, therefore, enabling them to interact (Statement II) would have been crucial to early cellular evolution. This property allows for the formation of a "primordial soup," where simple organic molecules could interact, form more complex compounds, and eventually lead to the development of proto-cells.Choice Bis the correct answer to this question.While surface tension is a property of water, it does not directly contribute to the formation of proto-cell membranes (Statement I) in the context of early cellular evolution. Proto-cell membranes are primarily formed by the self-assembly of amphipathic molecules like phospholipids, which align themselves in a bilayer in water due to their hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions.Organic molecules needed to remain in suspension for interactions, rather than settling quickly (Statement III). Water's density is well-suited for suspending organic particles, allowing them to remain available for biochemical reactions, while enabling gradual sedimentation over time.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they include one or more untrue statements.

list.content:
The karyogram shows a karyotype of a healthy human foetus.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc08017-69b8-4823-982a-12bb8e00c243/images/e3d89299-8c59-4872-a8af-84cb0cbaf394/BI1630%20fig1.png)

[Source: Adapted from National Cancer Institute (2013, January 21). File: Karyotype (normal). jpg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved April 28, 2024. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karyotype_(normal).jpg. Copyright free]Deduce, with a reason, the biological sex of the foetus.[1]The biological father of the foetus has haemophilia, and the biological mother is a carrier of the disease. Using a Punnett square, calculate the probability that the foetus has haemophilia.[3]Haemophilia occurs in approximately 1 in 6000 biological males and 1 in 100,000 biological females. Suggest a reason for this difference.[1]Much research has been conducted into the use of stem cells to treat genetic diseases. Outline the advantages and disadvantages of the use of adult stem cells over embryonic ones in stem cell therapy.[3]
list.markScheme:
anyoneof the following→\ce{ -> }​biologically maleBECAUSEthey have a Y chromosomeORthey have 22 pairs of homologous chromosomesAND1 pair of non-homologous sex chromosomes[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The foetus is biologicallymalebecause they have aY chromosome(✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following→\ce{ -> }​parental genotypes identified in the Punnett square; biological father:XXhY\ce{X^hY}XXhYANDbiological mother:XXHXXh\ce{X^HX^h}XXHXXh[1]→\ce{ -> }​offspring genotypes identified asXXHY,XXhY\ce{X^HY, X^hY}XXHY,XXhY[1]→\ce{ -> }​0.50OR50%OR12\frac{1}{2}21​[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc08017-69b8-4823-982a-12bb8e00c243/images/23e5eaf5-4187-4a5f-b4d9-7b165e6ae1be/1630.png)

The biological sex of the foetus is male, so it must inherit the Y chromosome from its biological father. The probability of a biologically male foetus having haemophilia is50 %(✓\checkmark✓).anyoneof the following→\ce{ -> }​it is a sex-linked recessive disease,ORthe gene is carried on the X chromosomeANDbiological males only have one X chromosome, so if they have the recessive allele, they will have the disease, whereas biological females with one copy would be carriers[1]→\ce{ -> }​for a biological female to have haemophilia, they would need to have two copies of the recessive allele, whereas biological males only need one copy of the recessive allele to have haemophilia[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Haemophilia is more common in biological males because it is asex-linked diseaseon theX chromosome.Biological maleshave onlyone X chromosome, so inheriting therecessive allele resultsin thedisease, whilebiological femaleswithtwo X chromosomescan becarriers without symptoms(✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following (at leastoneadvantage andonedisadvantage must be given to gain full marks)advantages:→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells can be obtained from the individual needing treatment, reducing the risk of immune rejectionWHILEembryonic stem cells may be rejected by the patient’s immune system[1]→\ce{ -> }​harvesting adult stem cells is generally less controversialORhas fewer ethical implications compared to embryonic stem cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells have a lower risk of producing tumours compared to embryonic stem cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cell therapies generally face fewer regulatory hurdles and greater public acceptance compared to therapies involving embryonic stem cells[1]disadvantages:→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells are multipotentORare often restricted in the number of cell types they can produceWHILEembryonic stem cells are pluripotentORcan differentiate into any bpdy cell type[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells are limited in number within adult tissuesORcan be challenging to obtainORcultureWHILEembryonic stem cells are more numerous OR easier to harvest[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells have less potential for long-term proliferationORdurability in cultureCOMPARED TOembryonic stem cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​adult stem cells are derived from fully developed tissues so typically more differentiated,WHEREASembryonic stem cells are derived from a very early developmental stage so less differentiated[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Oneadvantageof using adult stem cells in therapy is that they can be obtained from the patient,reducing the risk of immune rejection(✓\checkmark✓). Additionally, harvesting adult stem cells isless controversialand hasfewer ethical implications(✓\checkmark✓) compared to embryonic stem cells. However, adult stem cells aremultipotentandlimitedin thetypes of cells(✓\checkmark✓)  they can produce, unlike pluripotent embryonic stem cells. Moreover, adult stem cells areless numerousandharder to harvest(✓\checkmark✓) than embryonic stem cells.

list.title: Question 195
list.content:
The table shows genome sizes for several different species.OrganismGenome Size (base pairs)Escherichia coli(Bacterium)5 millionSaccharomyces cerevisiae(Yeast)12 millionDrosophila melanogaster(Fruit Fly)140 millionXenopus laevis(Frog)????Homo sapiens3 billionDescribe the challenges of predicting the size of the genome ofXenopus laevisbased on the information provided in the table.[2]Single-cell genome sequencing allows researchers to analyse the genetic material of individual cells. Cancer is characterised by significant genomic instability, leading to massive variations in genome size when compared to noncancerous cells.Explain how single-cell genome sequencing can be more useful than traditional genome sequencing for developing effective cancer treatments.[3]The diagram below depicts nanopore DNA sequencing technology.  This portable technology involves passing a single piece of DNA through a tiny pore in a membrane in an electrical field in a manner such that the current can reveal the DNA sequence.  This allows for the analysis of environmental DNA (eDNA), which consists of DNA fragments shed by organisms into their surroundings (e.g., skin cells, waste).  It can also give almost immediate results for shorter fragments, and sequence entire genomes in as little as 3 days.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bc9dbc7a-73a6-41de-bef4-c83dfff6f8fc/images/3d062db1-de82-446a-8141-4670a3bbbe8f/BI2802.png)

[Source: Adapted from National Institutes of Standards and Technology (2024, November 18)DNA Sequencing Method[image]. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 04:53, May 5, 2025 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:DNA_Sequencing_Method_ (8051510835).jpg&oldid=958458868.Public Domain]Discussonepotential benefit and one potential risk associated with the widespread use of portable DNA sequencing technologies.[2]Suggest ways whole-genome sequencing can contribute to our understanding of evolutionary relationships between species, and also to personalised medicine.[4]
list.markScheme: the following (award zero marks for a numerical prediction):→\ce{ -> }​genome size does not increase with complexity in a predictable manner[1]→\ce{ -> }​WHICH MEANSit is not possible to predict a genome size based on the information in the table[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The genome size of Xenopus laeviscannot be predicted(✓\checkmark✓) from the table because there isno correlationbetween organismcomplexity and genome size(✓\checkmark✓).anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​traditional whole-genome sequencing provides an average genomic profile of the whole organismORnot just the tumour[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-cell sequencing can show differences between the typical genome of that organism and the tumor[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-cell sequencing can show differences within the tumour itself[1]→\ce{ -> }​heterogeneity within the tumour can provide cliniciansORresearchers with clues as to the best treatment options[1]→\ce{ -> }​comparison of single-cell genome sequencing of tumour with originating tissue can help clinicians predict which treatment option will best allow healthy tissue to survive[1]→\ce{ -> }​single-cell sequencing facilitates the development of more personalised and effective therapies[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Traditional whole-genomesequencing provides an overall genomic view of awhole organism(✓\checkmark✓), giving us an average of the genetic information across all cells.Single-cell sequencingoffers a moredetailedperspective by revealingdifferences(✓\checkmark✓) between the typical genome of that organism and the tumour cells.  Heterogeneity within the tumour can provide clinicians and researchers with crucial clues for determining themost effective treatment options(✓\checkmark✓).anytwoof the following(must includeonebenefit andonerisk):benefits→\ce{ -> }​enables rapid identification of pathogens in remote or resource-limited areas[1]→\ce{ -> }​faster response time for public health interventions[1]→\ce{ -> }​tracking of endangeredORinvasiveORelusive species by eDNA without the need for lab facilities[1]→\ce{ -> }​identification of species present in an ecosystem based on eDNA without the need for lab facilities[1]→\ce{ -> }​genetic analysis at the point of careORon-site for rapid treatment response[1]→\ce{ -> }​individual empowermentORaccountability over their own health[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased speed of identification of criminal suspectsORdisaster victims[1]risks→\ce{ -> }​privacy concerns due to easy access to genetic data[1]→\ce{ -> }​misuse of genetic informationORgenetic discrimination[1]→\ce{ -> }​misinterpretation of results by non-experts may lead to incorrect medical or legal decisions[1]→\ce{ -> }​potential for higher error rate[1]→\ce{ -> }​potential for bioterrorism[1]→\ce{ -> }​technological advancements moving faster than legal regulatory framework leads to misuse and abuse[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:One potential benefit of portable DNA sequencing is that it can providefaster results(✓\checkmark✓) because the sequencing can be done on-site rather than sent to a lab, which can take days.  One possible risk is that DNA samples can be collected from the environmentwithout the consent of the people, raising importantethical concerns(✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following, at least one must be presented for each applicationevolutionary relationships→\ce{ -> }​allows for comparison of whole genomes across species[1]→\ce{ -> }​identifies conserved regions and genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​facilitates the study of evolutionary genetic changes such as gene duplication, loss, chromosomal alterations and horizontal gene transfer[1]→\ce{ -> }​generates data for analysing genome patterns of evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​extensive genetic data enables the creation of detailed and accurate phylogenetic trees[1]personalised medicine→\ce{ -> }​identifies genetic predispositions to disease[1]→\ce{ -> }​predict individual responses to drugs and medicines[1]→\ce{ -> }​characterise the genetic make-up of tumours to guide cancer treatment[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Whole-genome sequencing can contribute to the study of evolutionary relationships by identifying differences ingenetic patterns of evolution, such asgene duplication or lossandchromosomal duplication or loss(✓\checkmark✓).  It can alsoidentify conserved genesor regulatory sequences between species (✓\checkmark✓).  Whole-genome sequencing can contribute to personalised medicine through theidentification of genetic diseases(✓\checkmark✓) and predispositions to disease, as well as probable individual physiologicalresponses to treatmentoptions (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 196
list.content:
The graph below shows the results of an experiment conducted by a team of researchers investigating the relationship between the composition and melting point of different DNA samples. At the melting point, the DNA double helix separates into two individual strands.Two DNA samples were compared, one consisting of only PQ pairs and another one consisting of only RS pairs.  Letters P, Q, R and S represent different nitrogenous bases found in the DNA.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d59dd324-98c9-4e4e-91b6-758d5679701c/images/0881eea3-e69e-45cc-ad3b-7c9e377763b5/BI0321.png)

[ © Revision Village 2022]Based on the results presented in the graph, and your knowledge of nucleotide base pairing (between purines and pyrimidines), deduce which nitrogenous bases correspond to the letters P, Q, R and S.\hspace{2.5em}P\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{2.5em}Q\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{2.5em}R\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{2.5em}S\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}CytosineGuanineThymineAdenine\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}AdenineCytosineGuanineThymine\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}GuanineAdenineThymineCytosine\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}ThymineAdenineCytosineGuanine
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Adenine pairs up with thymine and cytosine pairs up with guanine. Hence, PQ or RS would either be adenine with thymine or cytosine with guanine (Choices AandD), but definitely notChoices BorC.Cytosine and guanine pairing has three hydrogen bonds, whereas the adenine and thymine pairing has only two hydrogen bonds. At95oC95^oC95oC, there is a smaller percentage of RS-rich DNA melted content compared to PQ-rich DNA.This shows that RS would be cytosine and guanine pairing (Choice D) and PQ is adenine and thymine. Because the extra hydrogen bond between C and G makes it more temperature resistant compared to A and T.
